message+desc: Good morning!^^ Ever in need of such excitement as life-on-a-line? For julgwangdae (rope acrobats), life is always on a tightrope, and purpose in entertaining through music and witty dialogues with eoritgwangdae (clowns on the ground). Watching the performance alone is an immense adrenaline rush (hence reserved as the main program of many village festivals)! And we are thrilled to be sharing with you the newly registered UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity, JULTAGI (tightrope walking).

They offer two tightrope performances a day year-round.$$really^^ i try to visit it later..thanks for your info$$why did't have any performance on December?$$remind me the film "The king and the clown"

message+desc:
Where is it?
Boracay, Aklan

How to Get There:
Fly from Manila to Caticlan. 

Or fly from Manila to Kalibo, then take a bus to Caticlan. 

Or take a boat from Manila to Caticlan.

What is it like?
When packing your bags for Boracay Island, shoes should be the least of your concerns. You'll be walking barefoot on the powder-fine sand most of the time. And sitting on it. And getting massages on it. You'll form quite an attachment to Boracay sand. Just please don't take any of it home! Leave the beach for others to enjoy.

Fun Fact:
Come dusk, young boys and girls take to the beach to begin sculpting impressive pieces of sand art. For a small fee, they can even personalize the sand art for you!

Photo by / Caption by:
Ryder Aquino / Nikki Golez
comments: nice  place  i be there  next month!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!$$I wish i could there..$$Boracay is nice, but far too commercialized for my liking. My experience there was nice. It is an enjoyable place, especially for the younger crowd! It clearly is a tropical paradise filled with natural beauty that rivals anything in the world.$$White Beach in Boracay is now included as one of the best beaches in the world, according to TripAdvisor, http://edition.cnn.com/2015/02/18/travel/tripadvisor-travelers-choice-best-beaches/index.html

message+desc:
Where is it?
Vinta Regatta Festival, Zamboanga

How to Get There:
Fly into Zamboanga from Manila, Cebu or Davao.

Or take a boat to Zamboanga from Manila.

What is it?
A vinta's sail is made up of vertical stripes of assorted colors that represent the colorful history of the peninsula's Muslim community. About a third of its population is made up of ethnic communities that give the region its unique flavor. These include the Tausugs, Samals, Yakans, Badjaos, and Subanens. Wait until you start hearing the people speak Chabacano ‚Äì arguably the suavest-sounding dialect because of its heavy Spanish influence.

Fun Fact:
Vinta is also the name of a Moro dance performed to commemorate the migration of the Filipinos. Dancers imitate the movement of the vintas by balancing on the tops of poles.

Photo by / Headline by:
Tourism Department Philippines / Donna Dimayuga

message+desc:
Start your day at Wajima Morning Market!
Wajima City is located on the northern shore of Noto peninsula in Ishikawa prefecture. This market has its history more than a thousand year„ÄÄand open every day except the 2nd Wednesday and 4th Wednesday of each month (and January 1‚Äì3 every year). You can taste various fresh local fish, produce, and of course, lacquerware which is famous in Wajima region.  
Please enjoy local morning market as well as Japanese culture experience!  
Morning„ÄÄMarkets:
http://www.jnto.go.jp/eng/attractions/shopping/market/morning.html

As of June 1st, anyone caught smoking in Seoul Plaza, Cheonggye Plaza and Gwanghwamun Square between 09:00 and 19:00 will be fined 100,000 won on the spot. The smoke-free zones will expand to 21 major parks by September and to 300 medi

I totally am in support of this ban!$$Korea actually turning into like Singapore, where every place is a smoke free except for a smoking area only.$$Dear,I totally agree with the ban coz smoking not good for health ~^^$$A stept in the right direction -- now to enforce traffic laws and make it illegal to argue with the police.$$yei,i agree about the bans.coz that's so bad for our healthy.$$But do you think it will be enforced?$$No they won't enforce them. Do they enforce any of their other laws? (:$$Interesting! I know sometimes people smoke in restaurants (even when there is a no-smoking sign). In that case it's ok to just ask them politely to stop. *^^*$$@KTO, yes! They go in the bathroom section and smoke! It's awful.$$Thats greeeeaaattttt!!!$$it might be enforced in the busiest of tourist areas, but I doubt anywhere else. Also, I would really like to see littering laws enforced (I'm assuming there are anti-littering laws)...$$wow i like daehan minguk... u guys so strict and it's good anyway...!! !$$Yes.Singapore ban smoking in a lot of place.It is good for Korea to do the same thing.$$I love this resolution, specially because I have asthma and even If I didn't, doctor's say that the hume is more dangerous for non smokers!$$Down with the bad and non healthy habits <3$$i truly like this idea! here in the philippines, particularly in davao city, our city mayor strongly enforces this smoking ban for almost 10years on public places. a fine of 10,000 pesos or 200,000 won more or less to whoever is caught. maybe the korean gov't should increase the fine so that smokers will religiously follow and be afraid of this law. message+desc:
The Blue Lagoon Oludeniz,  #Turkey

Olu Deniz, a beautiful inland bay that stretches behind the cape, is now closed to yachts. The reason this heavenly place is called Olu deniz ("Sea of the Dead") is attributed to the following legend;

Once a father and son were caught in a storm here and were in danger of sinking. The son claimed that if they approached the rocks ashore they could take shelter in a cove. The father on the other hand asserted that their ship would be driven onto the rocks and break up and that there were no coves around here anyway. In his terror of running around on the rocks, the father knocked his son (who was at the helm) into the sea with an oar and took over the helm himself. Just as the ship was about to hit the rocks on the cape, she turned into this calm, smooth watered bay. 

This is the reason they say the bay is called the Sea of the Dead, whereas what with the pine clad sandy beach stretched out like a tongue, the name "Paradise Bay" would be more fitting.

The Blue Lagoon of Olu deniz has calm, crytal clear waters which makes it ideal for a variety of water sports and a very safe place for children to swim. Part of the lagoon is now a protected area (and it`s a national park).

#Share & #Tag anyone you would like to go on a #Vacation with!
#Like our page to explore the world's hidden gems with Tripviss

message+desc:
Hello #VisitKorea fans! We want to know your opinion! Leave a comment and give "Like" (Y) 
When traveling to #Korea, which of the following #accommodation would YOU choose? ;)
1. Hotel
2. Motel
3. Youth Hostel (Guesthouses)
4. Hanok (Traditional Korean house)

To learn more about them, please visit the lodging section of our page ‚òû bit.ly/29xJKBH ^_^
comments:
THANK YOU ALL FOR YOUR OVERWHELMING RESPONSES <3 We'd read through every single one of them, and it seemed like Hostels/Guesthouses/AirBNB and Hanoks are two of the top choices! ^_^$$Thank you for all your wonderful and insightful comments. Will be traveling to Seoul to meet my niece for the first time and I was thinking hotel. But with all the wonderful reviews and opinions on hostels, I think I changed my mind. I will also try to incorporate a stay in an hanok. Thanks everyone :)$$3 - guest houses these days are comparable to hotels with sufficient comfort at a good budget...leaves you more pocket for many other activities to do in Korea :)) 

I wish to try 4 someday too.$$I've been to korea 4 times.. I'm prefering hostel because it's cheaper than hotel.. most of the hostel in korea are very clean and comfortable and worth for money.. since i'm a budget traveller.. i'll choose hostel as my fav accomodation most of the time during my stay in korea..üòÅ$$I always look for guesthouses since I travel alone most of the time. The price is quite affordable for people who don't mind small rooms and average cleanliness. You also get to meet new people during your stay~$$I haven't been to Korea , it depends on how much budget you have and where to go . For us who does not have a lot of money , but enough to visit Korea , a good budgeted place is much more affordable for us . Hanok will be good and a good affordable tour guide will be good .. I would love to experience to be living among Koreans , your culture , food , and much more . Thanks üòú$$Definitely hostel, the cheapest and most of the hostel near to public transport station.
I went twice to korea, i hope my 3rd time can be a hanok, wanna try... haha...$$It depends on my budget for the trip ~ but mostly my 1st priority is hostel bcos by staying in the hostel I can meet other travellers. However, occasionally I would like to stay at the hanok to experience the traditional culture of Korea or at the hotel as a reward for my self ^^$$Since I am a budget traveller, I always stay in hostel/guesthouse whenever I travel to Korea. But I also want to try to stay in a hanok if I can find an affordable one near the subway.$$for my 3 times visiting Korea, i stayed at hostel/ guesthouses. much cheaper and its clean. no problem at all. and i am comfortable with the staff :)$$Its depends on the budget. I would like to stay at the hanok house. If i travel with my family, i like everyone stay together.$$We came to Korea last fall and stayed in an AirBnB near Seoul Station. Is was really affordable for 2 people and close to everything! We plan to do it again this fall when we come back.$$I have never been to Korea, but that is in my plan. 
I think, because I love the classic style and history I would choose Hanok. That is beautiful, traditional, there is the soul of the Korean architecture. However I know that is expensive, I would choose it for just a short time period, than move to a hostel. There you can meet with lot of lovely people and that is not expensive, so you can save your money as well.$$For a budget traveller like me and sometimes solo traveller, hostel/guesthouse because it's cheap and I get to know new friends and it feels homey with the local owners/receptionist. I learn more about the culture. Money saved on the accommdation will be splurged on food and shopping. Still on my list on my list is the Hanok stay.$$I have been to Korea twice and have stayed there for a month each.  For a long staying traveller like me, I prefer to stay on a guesthouse considering the budget for accommodation.  I have stayed on guesthouses in Hongdae, Busan, Jeju and PyeongChang and everything was clean and organized.   The owners are very welcoming and helpful.  But I would love to try Hanok someday. Do you have any recommendations on affordable hanok to stay in?  Í∞êÏÇ¨Ìï©ÎãàÎã§.  üòä$$For my next trip I'm definitely staying at a Hanok house!!! I love the architectural beauty and simplicity of these houses and I've always wanted to stay in one. My last trip I stayed at an airbnb, I wasn't impressed.$$Hostel/guesthouses because usually it feels as if you are staying with a friends family so you learn more about the local culture. There is more of a personal touch. And Hanok stay also was surprisingly comfortable and a very unique experience. Anyone who visits Korea should try it at least once.$$I have stayed in AirBnB places and have found it much more affordable, especially since I can cook a few meals and do laundry easily. I would love to try a hanok but there is no way I could sleep on the floor.$$For my second  trip to Korea Ihave booked Hostel in the Hongdae area in Seoul as I love this area very much and would  like to meet other people$$Hanok. I always got good price and the experience was perfect. Due to the small size of the Hanok Guesthouses I could create a friendly relationship with the owner, they even acted like being my mother :), by which l could get closer to real Korean life.$$Annyeong KTO teams, i prefer to choose hostel because it's cheaper and affordable for me ... But someday i want to try to stay in a Hanok because it's very unique and beautiful. I want to feel how to stay in Korean traditional house like i usually see in Kdrama. Kamsahamnida üòÑ$$Hanok and I'd like to try to rent an apartment one day to live the Korean life but I think its so expensive. I'm also following the guest houses news and I think its a good idea too..

message+desc: According to the lunar calendar, it is #WinterSolstice today, also known as #Dongji (ÎèôÏßÄ). On this day, Koreans make and eat red bean porridge called patjuk (Ìå•Ï£Ω) as red beans symbolize the chasing away of evil spirits, and rice balls symbolize new life! Do YOU have a similar culture in your country? :D
comments: Yup. Chinese also called it Dongji to celebrate winter solstice. In fact the old Chinese saying, Dongji is most important celebration than Chinese New Year whereby celebrating the year's harvest and wish for better coming year. But Chinese New Year has overshadowed Dongji maybe because not all of us farm and we anticipate the Angpow, food, the long holidays and the atmosphere.$$We're having that too in Singapore ~ we call it 'tang yuan' Ê±§ÂúÜ in mandarin. This popular dish is a flavorsome spicy grilled chicken. Originally introduced by the people of Karang Taliwang Village, it has become a culinary icon of the island of Lombok. Ayam Taliwan...

message+desc:
‚ÄúWhen I look back at my time in Southeast Asia, my visit to the Philippines is one that sticks out the most,‚Äù writes English traveler Tommy Walker. See what made him enjoy his time here, and share this inspiring article with friends who haven‚Äôt been to the PH yet! 

http://www.rappler.com/life-and-style/travel/ph-travel/121534-philippines-travel-memories?utm_content=bufferdfdce&utm_medium=social&utm_source=facebook.com&utm_campaign=buffer
comments: Mabuhay Philippines! I arrived the first time January 1980 after teaching English in Seoul almost 6 months; I'd planned to travel 2 months but before I noticed I was here for 4 months and din't feel like leaving but took off to Thailand for 2 weeks, got homesick for the Philippines, came back one more time before heading for California after working my way around the world for almost 4 years. I ended up hooking up with my Filipina wife in South Korea Dec 19, 1983, found ourselves at the right time in the right place in 1984 so were able to buy our first Townhouse on Roxas Blvd March 1985. Now we're nearlt 62 years young loving and sharing life together for 32+ years. message+desc:
Lake Tazawa (Tazawa-ko), the deepest lake in Japan!
It is located in the central east of Akita Prefecture. The deepest point of the lake is 423.4 meters and shape is almost perfectly circle. However cold the weather can be in winter, the Lake is so deep that it wouldn‚Äôt freeze at all.

Let us tell you the myth about this girl ‚ÄúTatsuko‚Äù in the golden statue.
There was a girl, Tatsuko, in the area of Lake Tazawa. Everybody knew she was beautiful and attractive. One day when she realized she truly owns beauty, she started clinging to it. She did not want to lose neither her beauty nor the youth. She wanted them forever that she went to shrine to ask for a help. ‚ÄúGuanyin‚Äù(enlightenment being in Buddhism) suggested her to drink water of the lake as much as possible. She kept drinking with suffer, gradually, she turned into ‚Äútatsu‚Äù (dragon). Since then, she started living in the Lake. Her husband experienced the same thing in the northern lake. He, also in a dragon shape, came to Lake Tazawa, and they have lived together. Having two owners, Lake Tazawa got deeper and deeper.

More information about Lake Tazawa:
http://www.jnto.go.jp/eng/location/regional/akita/tazawako.html
comments: that is attractive story$$This is one of the most unforgettable Japan Prefecture scene in Korea drama : IRIS$$It is legend not true story.

message+desc:
Do you know this cat doll? This cat doll is called Maneki Neko (beckoning or welcoming cat) and it is popular in Japan as a lucky charm that invites happiness.  It is said that the one with its right paw raised invites money and the one with its left paw raised invites people. You can find them at souvenir shops or local craft shops. They are so cute!
More about Maneki neko, check out:
http://www.jnto.go.jp/eng/indepth/exotic/JapanesQue/1111/manekineko.html
photo courtesy: Yasufumi Nishi

message+desc:
The Banyak Islands are a group of sparsely inhabited island located in the Aceh Singkil Regency, between Simeulue and Nias, off the western coast of Sumatera, Indonesia. It consisting 0f 99 small land masses and directly facing the Indian Ocean. The largest island in the group is Tuangku (Great Banyak), with the principal town of Alaban. Two other major island located either side of Tuangku are Bangkaru and Ujung Batu. Tuangku is separated from Bangkaru by a fault line. http://ow.ly/RIDiO

#WonderfulIndonesia #PesonaIndonesia
comments: I love the Banyak Islands. I visited them 1993 üíï$$So proud of Indonesia. We have thousands of beautiful islands!

message+desc: Starting from last week, Seoul Plaza, Cheonggye Plaza, and Gwanghwamun Square were designated NON-SMOKING areas. Starting from June 1st, you may even get a fine of 100,000 if you're smoking in these areas  (yikes!). Do you think this policy is a good thing or a bad thing?^^;;In an effort to reduce the effects of second-hand smoke, the city of Seoul has passed legislation that bans smoking in 3 major downtown areas. Starting from March 1, Seoul Plaza, Cheonggye Plaza, and Gwanghwamun Square will be nonsmoking areas. The city plans to gradually designate additional smoke-
comments: A good thing definitely $$Absolutely Good...... and Lucky I'm not a smoker$$I personally wish they would enforce an anti-spitting policy...heehee.~Kimberly$$anti-littering as well...!$$The similar policy has been implemented in Singapore for sometime with the main objective of deterring people from smoking,which may cause lung cancer.Definitely a favourable policy.$$and anti hawking up greenies in ur ear policy$$Yeah I am very happy to hear this.   I love Korea but have a bad smoking  allergy, so I am happy to hear they are making changes.   We did it in Canada a few years back, maybe 5 and it makes most poeples' lives easier.$$Btw the heavy fine is also applicable to spitting at n littering public places in Singapore.The aim is to promote a clean,green n healthy Singapore. The heavy fine is imposed as a good deterrent.$$I'm glad they caught onto this! America is ahead of the game. But it's nice you can bring the kids more places when there is no smoking.$$good thing. it promoting & encourages no smoking.$$This is real good, in Australia you can't even smoke in the pubs too since 2 years which is really good.$$Definitely a good thing!!! Less smokes gives you longer life!!! And less pain for your wallet!$$where is the human right of smoker? govt shud study the culture of this country instead of following others blindly! stop them smoking is same like stop them drinking? right? further they paid tax too when they bought their ciggy.......$$It's a good thing. Everyone can enjoy cleaner air. Besides, smoking is bad for our health ;-)$$the places will look more cleaner ...hurrey..!$$Good thing- it helps to make those areas family friendly!$$Someone could burn the grass there! There are plenty of other places to smoke, anyway!

message+desc:
Where is it?
Puerto Princesa, Palawan

How to Get There:
Fly into Puerto Princesa from Busuanga, Cebu, Davao, Iloilo or Manila. 

What is it?
Sea anemones are known as "the flowers of the sea," and are named after the terrestrial flower of the same name. Beware ‚Äì their beauty is paired with a formidable bite, as the slightest touch on their tentacles triggers the release of a harpoon-like filament with painful neurotoxin.

Fun Fact:
While mobile, sea anemones are only capable of moving at three or four inches an hour.

Photo by / Headline by:
Tourism Department Philippines / Magnus Ahmad
comments: Is it safe there? Would love to visit$$It is, I waz there Feb of last year. Its a paradise, you'll forget your worries.$$Enchanted Beauty! Beware. :-D

message+desc:
Ajmer - A place of divinity for people of all faiths

Founded in the seventh century by Ajaipal Chauhan, Ajmer derives its name from Ajaymeru, the invincible hill, at the foot of which the city stands today. Surrounded by the Aravalli mountain range, Ajmer is an oasis located between green hills.
Ajmer is a popular pilgrimage; the Dargah Sharif ‚Äì the tomb of the Sufi Saint Khwaja Moinuddin Chisti is revered by the Muslims.
Ajmer is also the base for visiting Pushkar, the abode of Lord Brahma; Pushkar Lake is a sacred spot for the Hindus. During the month of Kartik (October/November) devotes throng in large numbers here to bathe in the sacred lake. 

- See more at: http://www.incredibleindia.org/travel/destination/ajmer

message+desc:
Ï∂îÏÑù(Chuseok; Korean Thanksgiving) is by far the biggest and most important holiday in Korea. It is a time when family members from near and far come together to share food and stories, and to give thanks to their ancestors for the abundant harvest. This year, Chuseok Day falls on September 30th.

Find out more about Ï∂îÏÑù: http://bit.ly/SkPsnu

message+desc:
Where is it? 
Calanggaman Island, Leyte

What is it? 
By those who know about it, this ten-hectare hidden gem is adored for its supremely fine white sands. But the real adventure begins below the surface ‚Äîwith up to 30-meter visibility and an expansive reef, this marine reserve also provides a mystifying dive experience.

How to get there: 
Fly from Manila to Calbayog or Tacloban

Fun Fact: 
The island gets its name from the Cebuano word for bird, possibly owing to the two sandbars that stretch out like wings from its shores.

Photo by/Headline by: 
Jeffrey Bautista / Magnus Ahmad

message+desc:
Fruit picking in summer!
There are several orchards in Japan offering fruit-picking experiences to the public on a pay by weight, per piece or all-you-can-eat basis. In Japan, it is one of the popular weekend activities with friends or families with small children.
Currently, peaches, blueberries, watermelons, plums, melons are in season. Tourist can certainly experience this, and it is a great opportunity to taste fresh local ‚Äúmade in Japan‚Äù fruits.
Day tour is also available, and you can find the schedule and location on line.
For further information: http://www.jnto.go.jp/eng/attractions/dining/food/jfood_11.html
http://jnto.org.au/adventure-outdoors/fruit-picking/

message+desc:
Many firework displays are going on right now, but have you enjoyed small fireworks that you can hold in your hand?

Among these handheld fireworks, Senko Hanabi (a sparkler) is the most popular one.
Once you light the sparkler, you have to stay still as possible since the tiny tiny fireball can fall so easily.  

People enjoy the beautiful sparkles and fragility, and this is definitely one of summer features in Japan. :)

More details: http://www.jnto.go.jp/eng/indepth/cultural/feeljapanesque/fireworks.html

message+desc:
Where is it?
Puerto Princesa, Palawan

What is it?
Puerto Princesa Underground River is a UNESCO World Heritage Site, and one of the 7 New Wonders of the World.

message+desc:
Where is it?
Siargao, Surigao del Norte

How to Get There:
Fly from Manila to Surigao (one hour), then take a boat to Siargao.

Or take a bus from Manila or Davao to Surigao, then take a boat to Siargao.

Or take a boat from Manila to Surigao, then take a boat to Siargao.

What is it?
Hang ten on Cloud 9 ‚Äî a rip-roaring reef wave that's surfer heaven. The first surfers in the area loved it so much, they named it after their favorite Filipino chocolate bar.  Don't forget to check out Sohoton Cave. It's a labyrinth worth exploring, with clear waters, stalactites and limestone rocks. This place is only accessible at low tide.

Fun Fact:
Did you know that "The Surfing Capital of the Philippines" has inspired a song?  Ukelele artist Eddie Florano wrote one called "Surfin' in Siargao." It's included in the 2006 Ukelele World: Acoustic & Power Ukelele compilation album.

Photo by / Headline by:
Tourism Department Philippines / Donna Dimayuga
comments: As an alternative, you can have a vacation in an exciting tropical island and go mountaineering at the highest elevation in the whole Visayan region at Canlaon city Negros Oriental. From Cebu city you can go to Toledo by bus or van then hop on a one hour ride by ferryboat and hop off in San Carlos Negros. Ask around for the Sipaway islet and how to go to Canlaon city.

message+desc:
The RSAF Open House 2016 is back this weekend and it's completely FREE to visit!

Ths TSL team went down to explore Paya Lebar Air Base and here's what to expect! There's also rock climbing, air shows and the chance to sit in four different planes. You even get to sit in a cockpit! Kids will be entertained by the booths at the carnival section.

Location: Paya Lebar Air Base (PLAB) 
Date & Time: 21 & 22 May, 9am to 6pm daily

Follow TheSmartLocal.com and you'll never run out of things to do!

Getting There:

Free Shuttle Buses with RSAF-issued authorised bus labels from Eunos Bus Interchange and Kovan Hub (Shuttle bus operation starts at 8.30 am and ends at 5:30 pm at both locations. Buses leave both locations at 10-minute intervals.)

SBS Bus No. 90 (please refer to the SBS Bus operation timings). Visitors should alight at Air Force Museum.
Registered Taxis with the Land Transport Authority, i.e. taxis from Comfort, CityCab, SMRT, Trans-Cab, Premier and Prime.

Model: Symone Maria Oei

message+desc:
The Takayama Spring Festival will be held on April 14, 15 at Takayama city, Gifu pref. The festival is considered one of the most beautiful festivals in Japan. A large parade of 1,000 people is staged, making you feel as if you have slipped back to the 15th Century, especially because of the costumes and music performances. According to cherry blooming forecast, Takayama starts to bloom April 15th. Hope it will be blooming little earlier than the forecast, and could enjoy the beautiful cherry blossom at the festival!
Location
http://www.jnto.go.jp/eng/location/regional/gifu/takayama.html
Detail information
http://www.jnto.go.jp/eng/location/spot/festival/takayamafes.html
¬©Takayama City
comments:
kya baat hai......What a collections..nice friend....$$can't wait to be there :)$$Last year I was in Takayama!!!$$Is the festival always on April 14 and 15? We are planning a big trip for next year.$$So beauty ,excite to be there$$Love Takayama !
 stayed at Temple Zenko-ji...
  very unique experience !$$Is the parade going to be held both days? 14 & 15?
We'll get to takayame on the 15th, are we going to make it? At what time does the parade start? I'll appreciate some more information. The web site you link to doesn't have much information. Agirato gozaimasu:))

message+desc:
Hakone is a popular destination not only for its scenic views of Mt. Fuji, but also for the many impressive art museums that can be found there. Museums in Hakone are filled with famous Japanese works of art, as well as unique exhibitions found nowhere else in the world!

Learn more: http://japan-magazine.jnto.go.jp/en/1702_museum.html
comments:
Definitely a favourite of mine, especially as it's so close to Tokyo it's great for a day-trip. Train in the morning, soak in the onsen and then a luxurious Odakyuu Romance Car back in the evening. Heaven...$$Loved the open air sculpture park, although we didn't have long to look round ...$$I love museum, but not too sure about the others. I think the one about samurai would appeal to all. I love the open air/outdoor one too.$$Still haven't been there, maybe next time !!!!$$We (Because We Camp) would love to go back to Japan and film this!$$You can also discover the Hakone region by road ;)
http://www.hoshinoresorts-magazine.com/en/hakone-region-japan-travel-historic-road/$$Hakone is a place where you need to find out many hidden interesting things. General tour will not impress you much. 

Fine art photographs of Japan, France, Italy, China
https://www.facebook.com/emerald.photographics.gallery$$It's so beautiful there. I Love Hakone.$$Hakone has a great English Facebook page with a chatbot. Ask questions and learn more. Like if you like Hakone! 
https://m.facebook.com/HakoneTravel/

message+desc:
Eat Japanese cold noodle and stay cool!

"Somen" is firm crisp noodle, made by twisting them like a rope and straightening them, it is usually served cold in iced-water with a light flavored dipping sauce.
Main famous somen producing area is Hyogo Pref. Nara Pref. etc. 
There are many somen restaurants and tourists can enjoy flowing noodles.
 
Hyogo Pref.
http://www.jnto.go.jp/eng/location/regional/hyogo/index.html
http://www.hyogo-tourism.jp/english/category/food.html

Nara Pref.
http://www.jnto.go.jp/eng/location/regional/nara/index.html
 http://www.pref.nara.jp/25539.htm
comments: That's what I had for lunch today! Great in beastly hot weather.$$That actually looks really good.

message+desc:
The TSL team takes a break from writing listicles and reads one by Sylvia Lim!

She lists 5 reasons why Marine Parade GRC voters should vote for The Workers' Party. (Okay she gotta work on her listicle writing skills lol)

http://mustsharenews.com/sylvia-lim-goes-all-buzzfeed/
comments:
In my opinion, 5 reasons not to vote for WP as follows:
1. Wayang Party (WP) - make a lot of noise at rally but keep quiet in Parliament
2. Flip flop like roti prata, first, your party - Gerald complained about too much foreigners 4 years ago. Now he complained about the u-turn on immigrant policy which is hurting business ?? So what do u all want? Complain everyone can but where is your proposed solution 3? 
3. Like to launch personal attacks on PAP candidates - called LKY a liar and Shanmugan a barking dog - is this ur so called a first world parliament ??
4. Greed for Power - have not shown us results in terms of managing a GRC well yet going after a few more GRCs n SMCs. 
5. Growing Arrogance - see themselves as the best of the best n disregard the other opposition parties - if you can't respect others how do u expect others to respect you$$1. So if we vote for WP, there will be less senseless change? Can the WP stop it?

2. Three bad policies? There's an entire book on his achievements. Go google it.

3. People don't understand or know how difficult it is to persuade anyone to come forward and be a Minister. Having to balance conflicting demands from all sectors of society is an impossible and thankless task. Whoever becomes a Minister will always suffer brickbats because no policy can satisfy everyone. Ask yourself, how many people are willing to put themselves in the firing line knowing they can never satisfy anyone, and they will be flamed no matter what they do. Yes, Chuan-Jin can still contribute in other ways, but how many are willing and able to be a Minister? It is so damn hard lah, please.

4. Accomplished team? I looked up Bernard Chen and he has only worked for only less than one year. And you expect me to believe he can run a town council?? YJJ and the rest have only started to work the ground this year. Previously, only saw YJJ in Joo Chiat and nowhere else. I don't think that's as accomplished as the rest of the MPs who have been here for more than one term.

5. Agree, and national interest to some like me means Vote PAP to make the Opposition work harder!$$WP stop talking nonsense lah... I am not going to vote for you.. my vote goes to PAP.$$So what solutions do u have for the above huh???$$OK....  What actually ARE the 5 reasons ?$$Since when this site became political? 

????

comments:
Hello!
I am Kamilla and I am a professional freelance interpreter offers interpreting services in Moscow and all over Russia. I have interpreted during business and financial negotiations, machinery installations, international fairs, quality and production audits, seminars/training sessions, and the visits of official delegations.

message+desc:
Kepulauan Togean di Sulawesi Tengah menjadi salah satu basis para suku Bajo yang tinggal di lautan. Terletak di Teluk Tomini, Sulawesi Tengah, secara administratif wilayah ini berada di Kabupaten Tojo Una-Una dan dikenal kaya akan terumbu karang dan berbagai biota laut yang langka dan dilindungi. Dibentuk oleh aktivitas vulkanis, pulau ini ditutupi oleh tumbuh-tumbuhan yang subur dan rimbun sekaligus dikelilingi oleh formasi bukit karang, tempat bagi beberapa binatang laut seperti kura-kura hijau untuk tinggal dan berkembang biak. bit.ly/1mZOceI

#WonderfulIndonesia #PesonaIndonesia

Have a peaceful life this year and more blessings and opportunities to come$$In the middle of a South Korean winter, there are dogs shivering and whimpering in freezing, open cages. They live their entire lives in factory farm conditions. They have no freedom, no affection, nothing that makes them feel good. And they‚Äôll be butchered so humans can eat their meat.

I have to be honest regardless of some cruel and archaic cultural tradition I do not understand why this practice is allowed to continue. I know there are many animal rescue groups who are trying desperately to stop the senseless abuse, cruelty and butchering of these poor animals.

It is my hope that continued pressure by animal rights groups, and a loud voice from various media groups, including Social Media will help but an end to the blight of these animals. Your voice would be greatly appreciated.
Regards

Where do you think this photo was taken? This is the Kanazawa station, Ishikawa pref. The Station was selected as one of the World‚Äôs most beautiful train stations on the Travel+Leisure Magazine. The wooden gate called "Tsuzumi-mon" made with image of a Japanese hand drum used in Kaga Hosho, a traditional No play of Kanazawa, and the glass dome called„ÄÄ"Motenashi (Welcome)-dome"  designed as a huge umbrella. It expresses hospitality to all visitors. The exquisite beauty of these structures perfectly expresses the two facets of Kanazawa as a modernizing city that is deeply respectful of tradition at the same time.
Visit Kanazawa and enjoy the architecture!
Destination guide: http://www.jnto.go.jp/eng/location/regional/ishikawa/kanazawa.html

message+desc:
Where is it? 
Ifugao, Luzon

What is it like? 
According to the Cordillera myth, the Ifugao people were created from Wigan, the god of Skyworld. Legend has it that Wigan gave the rice-terrace farming Ifugaos the first sacred rice. It's believed to be of the ipugo (rice of god) variety, which amazingly still flourishes despite certain the harsh conditions of the mountain ranges.

Fun Fact: 
There are more than 20 different cultural dances in this region alone. Each dance is specifically used to celebrate a family occasion or community milestone.

Photo by/Author: 
Tourism Department Philippines/Jao Bautista
comments:
Went there.  Bought a beautiful man's waist bag from one dancer that had metal pieces which "tinkle" when shaken.  Lovely people. Sweet and giving.  Did some hiking in the rice terraces...met wonderful people there.$$huh igorot i mzz that costume$$its more fun in the philippines

eating rice grown and harvested from rice terraces

message+desc:
Watched the show "A Beautiful Mind" about a mathematical genius? Few would know our PM was one too. 

While our PM was studying mathematics at Cambridge, he attained the status of 'Senior Wrangler', regarded as one of the ‚Äúgreatest intellectual achievements‚Äù in Britain. He could have went on to become a world renowned mathematician, but chose to come back and help govern Singapore.

Here are 8 facts you should know about our PM. Happy Birthday PM Lee!Today is Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong's 65th birthday.

To mark the occasion, we'd like to share some reasons why he's the coolest prime minister around.

https://mustsharenews.com/coolest-pm-lee/
comments:
In light of recent developments, would you say he has handled our relationship with China, the USA and Malaysia well? These are issues that are critical to our survival. I appreciate that your site has the right to like Lee Hsien Loong, the man, as a personality (for his cool posts, math skills and lightsaber collection).
But the Prime Minister is not merely a personality to idolise, he has a very important role to play in ensuring our future. However, all the points you listed may not be all that useful for that.$$Bec he is the highest pay PM in the world managing the smallest square area...? 

Indeed he is the coolest!$$I wish fellow Singaporeans who are on the extreme opposite end of his pay scale can be as happy as he is on any given day !$$Prime minister with the fattest pockets. Not cool at all.$$Because SG pays him $millions - much much more than any other PM in the world........?

Photo source: Mandala Blue YogaYoga has been practiced for many hundreds of years, dating back to ancient times in India. Today, Yoga has become a lifestyle and health trend, now followed all over the world. The word Yoga is taken from Sanskrit, meaning ‚Äúintegration, or union‚Äù.

message+desc:
Where is it? 
Apo Island, Negros Oriental

What is it?
Both a volcanic island and a marine reserve, this island has become a favorite diving destination in the southern Philippines. Its most popular site is Coconut, where sea turtles and sea snakes are regulars. But the spotlight belongs to the small-bodied white tip reef sharks which only grow up to five feet long.

How to get there: 
Fly from Manila to Dumaguete.

Or take a bus from Cebu to Oslob, then take the Roll-On Roll-Off (RORO) ferry to Dumaguete.

Then take a bus from Dumaguete to Zamboanguita, and transfer to an outrigger boat to take you to Apo Island.

Fun Fact: 
If you fancy corals, you‚Äôll love this place. Most of the country‚Äôs 400+ species can be found in this small space.

Photo by/Headline by: 
Tourism Department Philippines / Jao Bautista

message+desc:
Every year on Dec. 17, 18 and 19, HAGOITA-ICHI or shuttlecock and battledore fair will be held at Senso-ji Temple in Asakusa, Tokyo.
HAGOITA is a wooden paddle with a handle used for playing a New Year game called HANETSUKI, however, the thing sold at HAGOITA-ICHI are not for practical use. They are, in fact, good-luck charms for ornamental purposes and usually displayed in the house as a New Year‚Äôs ornament.
It will be great fun to visit there and you can definitely find exciting atmosphere both from visitors and venders. 

Related information;
http://www.jnto.go.jp/eng/location/spot/festival/hagoitaichi.html
http://www.gotokyo.org/en/kanko/taito/event/hagoita.html

message+desc:
Small Airports adalah bandara kecil dengan jumlah penumpang kurang dari 5 juta orang/tahun.

Di Indonesia sendiri terdapat beberapa small airports, diantaranya Komodo (189 ribu penumpang/tahun), Bandara Cut Nyak Dien Aceh (27 ribu penumpang/tahun), dan banyak lagi lainnya.

Bandara Soekarno hatta sendiri mencapai 62 juta penumpang/tahun. 

Karena itu, Angkasa Pura Airports bekerjasama dengan Airports Council International (ACI) Asia Pacific, menyelengggarakan ACI Small and Emerging Airports Seminar di bali tanggal 20-22 Oktober mendatang. http://indonesia.travel/id/news/detail/1432/airports-council-international-aci-asia-pacific-di-bali
comments: I think indonesia has many small airport spread at small islands and big islands for instance pioneer airport,for small plane based on java island,bali island,biak island, sumatera,and many other.

message+desc:
Have you ever seen a church looks like located inside of the site of a Buddhist temple? 
Francisco de Xavier Memorial Church, Hirado city, Nagasaki prefecture was constructed in 1913 and it was relocated to next to Komyoji Temple in 1931. Please check the photo below, church and temple are visible to overlapped each other.
You can enjoy rich nature and exotic Asia-Europe mixed culture in Hirado. 

More information:
http://www.jnto.go.jp/eng/location/regional/nagasaki/hirado.html
http://www.visit-nagasaki.com/spots/detail/532
http://www.jnto.go.jp/eng/location/spot/histarch/hiradodutchtradinghouse.html
comments:
What a wonderful idea. Other countries should have more of such places to show how different religions can all coexist harmoniously and peacefully.$$very beautiful thank$$Hirado is my hometown. And this landscape is near my home.

message+desc:
Where is it? 
Malaybalay City, Bukidnon

What is it like? 
The city is a refuge for seven indigenous groups thought to be the first inhabitants of the province. The Kaamulan Festival celebrates centuries-old customs with a huge fiesta!

How to get there: 
Fly from Manila, Cebu, Iloilo or Davao to Cagayan de Oro. Then take a bus to Bukidnon.

Fun Fact: 
Malaybalay City is home to the endangered Philippine Eagle.

Photo by/Headline by: 
Tourism Department Philippines/Meggy De Guzman
comments: It's more FUN in BUKIDNON

message+desc:
ZAZEN, or Zen Meditation is a form of mental or spiritual method of training. 
There are two major Zen sects, RINZAI and SOTO. Generally, meditators sit in lotus position against a wall in the RINZAI sect, and in the SOTO sect, meditators sit in facing a wall. 
If you would like to study more, please refer to the following link;
SOTO http://global.sotozen-net.or.jp/eng/practice/zazen/howto/
RINZAI http://www.rinzaizen.org/

Related information;
http://www.jnto.go.jp/eng/indepth/cultural/experience/w.html
http://www.jnto.go.jp/eng/indepth/cultural/kie/zen/
http://japan-magazine.jnto.go.jp/en/1308_zen.html
comments: I tried once in a monastery in Kyoto. Great culture experience.$$Grace Lin I just had a flashback to Komazawa days! Going to Japan Jan and April... Very excited xx$$Than a japanese to a foreigner a fan many, good one this how?$$Yes, the good old memories!

message+desc:
For first-time visitors, Manila can be an overwhelming city. But its rich culture and lively nightlife is not to be missed. Pulse Radio gives you a quick guide in navigating the city even if you‚Äôve only got 48 hours. 

http://pulseradio.net/articles/2015/01/48-hours-in-manilaOften referred to as Southeast Asia's most underrated capital, Manila is chaotic and thrilling; a city overflowing with life, which is steadily increasing in popularity with adventurous travellers. The Philippines stands firmly as the epicentre of the ...
comments: METRO MANILA, regardless of what people say (Pinoys or non Pinoys)...I still like to go there...for shopping, relaxation, historical walk, entertainment etc...many of my friends went there and HATE it...coz they simply don't know about the place, the culture, people and the language...so, for me Manila is still Manila AND I still like to go to 'Lungsod Ng Maynila'...‚ò∫ "It's More Fun In The Philippines" lol$$Manila, regardless of what pinoys say and how much criticism it gets, is still home for many people. And no matter what people say, I am proud of this city. Just because the news says bad things about it doesn't mean it can happen to everyone. I haven't heard any of my french friends say bad things about Paris although it doesn't feel safe there at all times. And NYC is a reminder that thieves do exist amongst the living. So please be careful about your criticisms, a lot of us expat pinoys do our share in promoting not only our islands but also Manila and your comments don't help much! A little generosity and positivity will do.$$My italian friends they love Metro Manila. They have seen also the beautiness and ugliness and ofcourse they prefer the safer areas but they defenitely love Metro Manila$$Just go to Makati and Bonifacio city and forget the rest there is nothing to see there and I grew up in Paco .$$Remember.. Every places has beauty. But not everyone can see it.  For me Manila is quiet beautiful$$i missed it....there's no place like home iba pa rin yung maynila...$$The oldest city kaya mayaman sa history'$$I used to live in Hidalgo St. Quiapo. If you talk about safety maybe Manila isnt the place for you. But if you wish to enjoy and know the rich culture of the country you can find all here.$$For tourists, Manila is great...but for living my her....I can' t stand it...$$Brian Mason what's your address?$$Just hang in Eastwood city so safe$$Alan: in case there are spots you haven't hit yet.$$You may skip manila mam/sir",,its up to you",,if you want to go straight ahead to your plans in going directly to our different islands of your choice!!",,,$$This itiniary is only for party animals$$Fix the poverty, the awful airport, the traffic jams, the pollution and the smell of urine and it maybe OK

message+desc:
Aoi Festival, well known as one of the 3 major annual festivals in Kyoto, will be held on May 15th. Over 500 people wearing traditional clothes, which nobles used to wear in Heian Period (794Ôºç1192), are going to parade all the way from the Kyoto Imperial Palace to the Kamigamo Shrine (About 5 hours).You will be able to see superb traditional costumes as well as make-up. Also, please don't forget to eat Yakimochi (Japanese steamed rice bun stuffed with sweet red bean paste) when you visit the Kamigamo Shrine. It's been loved by local people for long! 
Now are you getting interested in Kyoto?
More info: http://www.jnto.go.jp/eng/location/spot/festival/aoimatsuri.html
The parade route: http://www.kyokanko.or.jp/aoi/junkou.html
comments: "Aoi" is not hollyhock. It is "saishin" a woodland plant called wild ginger in the genus Asarum.

message+desc:
$30 Budget Challenge! 
Here are some ways in which you can spend your money wisely! With this budget, what would you like to experience most in Seoul? :D 
#ShoppingInKorea #ThirtyDollarsBudgetChallenge #VisitKorea
comments:
I would love to explore Seoul fully...do a Han River Cruise, lock my love in at Namsan Tower, shop all night in Myeongdong, eat every kind of Binsu, Noraebang, Visit the palaces and temples, Visit the Hanok village and explore everything I possibly can. I would never sleep! 
With my 30dollars though I would buy 2 locks and lock in my love at Namsan Tower and then buy some Binsu and eat it while overlooking the whole of Seoul from Namsan tower.$$Shop a little, streetfood and then end it at jjimjilbang. ^^$$I love Korean fashion. I will definitely be where I ca shop clothes and ill eat dumplings too..$$jjimjilbang experience and foodtrip in a tent ^_^$$So sweet :-) :-) I will go with the street food$$Jimjibang experience than eating & drinking @ food tent,gets the chance to blend in w the locals. :)$$i would try to challenge myself with head to toe outfit from total of $30 :) how about you?$$all looks wonderful and fun!!!  I Want all!!!!$$i would like to eating and drinking at food tent also jjimjibang experience ... #ShoppingInKorea #ThirtyDollarsBudgetChallenge #VisitKorea$$eat and drink at a food tent, eat some more street food at gwangjang market then stay overnight at a jjimjilbang :-)$$eating and drinking at food tent then jjimjilbang! :D$$I love to eat so I will spend my üí≤30 in üá∞üá∑ by buying street food in Myeongdong and Namdaemun. I will also try to eat chicken and drink soju at food tent. Thinking about this makes me want to #VisitKorea so soon.$$After window shopping at vintage market and after eat and drinking at food tent, i would ending it with experience Jjimjibang =D$$Street food, pojangmacha, then jjimjilbang to end the day. üòÄ$$Street food at Gwangjang Market of course :D$$spa at jijimbang experiance 13.000KR, eat tteokbokki 3.000KR,and the remaining shop at myeongdong.

message+desc:
You and your friend can lounge at this luxurious resort for 3 days when you win #TagTheFun photo contest!

Astoria Palawan is an eco-friendly resort found in the famous Puerto Princesa in Palawan. The establishment is situated on a five hectare mango orchard with a retention pond that is used for recreation as a source of water. The materials adapted for the construction are green building materials. With its rustic and modern architecture, they aim to be loyal on having an environmental design to ensure travelers feel one with nature throughout their stay.

Astoria Palawan has 40 spacious and elegant rooms. The studio rooms are 38 sqm, the 1 bedroom suite is 56 sqm while the 2 bedroom suite is 91 sqm. All accommodations have either a cozy king size bed or two queen size beds. The suites have separate living and dining areas. Amenities also include TV with cable, kitchenette, air conditioned rooms and complimentary coffee. Guests can enjoy the numerous facilities such as the swimming pool, dining areas, and avail of several tours such as exploring the Honda Bay Islands or the Puerto Princesa Subterranean River National Park.

www.agoda.com/morefunph
http://bit.ly/1KZRZiv
comments: sounds good but scary to go for holidays way back home at the moment...

message+desc:
Why don‚Äôt you visit HOZUKI ICHI in Tokyo!
This fair is usually held in June and July at some temples or shrines, such as Atago Shrine on June 23 & 24 and most famous one at Sensoji Temple in Asakusa on July 9 & 10. It is told that people visiting this temple on this day can be counted as visiting the temple for a whole life.
‚ÄúHozuki‚Äù which can be called ‚ÄúWinter Cherry‚Äù was known as a medical herb and people used to buy this while visiting the temple. There are almost 450 vendors in the precincts of Sensoji Temple.
In this season, during your stay in Japan, you may find the beautiful red ‚ÄúHozuki‚Äù at the Market!
 http://www.gotokyo.org/en/kanko/taito/event/hozmaturi.html

Calendar Events June 2014>
http://www.jnto.go.jp/eng/pdf/event/calendar_events_201406.pdf

Ounnet, are you japan?

The color of Torii is not only vermilion, some are made of stone or even black color, however, vermilion's is the most representative.
It is said that there are almost 80,000 shrines in Japan. 
How many shrines in Japan did you visit already?

message+desc:
If there is just one thing you read about the Paris attacks today, make it this.

This is dedicated to all our Muslim friends out there who now have to bear the world's hatred. It should be directed at Terrorists, not Muslims. But sadly, people are going to generalise.

It is unfair that a tiny group with a distorted view of religion could cause so much distress to both Muslims and Non-Muslims.
comments:
Please be aware that The Islamic State aka ISIS (Islamic State of Iraq & Syria) does not & will not represent all Muslim & Islam as a religion.

No religion preach violence or to harm others nor themselves. Terrorism is not an religion but an act of immorality against humanity & everything good that comes out from Peace.

We as an individual can help to spread the understanding. A small action against terrorism, help to keep humanity & harmony in place. We are all a part of something bigger. Fight terrorism!

message+desc:
Where is it?
Stilts Resort, Batangas

How to Get There:
Take a bus to Batangas from Cubao or Pasay.

What is it?
Stilts is a resort in Calatagan, Batangas with eight cottages perched over water. Each cottage has a wooden staircase that leads right into the water, so you can dive right in!

Photo by / Headline by:
Miguel Teotico / Rachel Teotico
comments: wow beautiful home is that near by the ocean breath taking$$i've been there last month. check this.$$Coffee anyone? Batangas has the rarest coffee$$Bing Bing, the website is www.stiltscalataganbeachresort.net....  Please do come and visit Stilts!$$I want to go there..how much per night?$$This damn place is so ridiculously expensive! Seriously! Why? WTF.$$Actually, it's not that expensive. It's the same prices as most of the other resorts, if not less. Maybe it was just expensive for you, Espe del monte?$$Expensive? No way!  No where in the world can one find this sort or quality at this price.  It is very affordable for what you get (the cottages sleep rooms sleep 4-12 people depending on which one).  Food is great. Complete class.  Not many places in the Philippines pay this much attention to detail.  A very reasonable priced resort for the quality you get. I brought a group of students there and it was well within our budget.

message+desc:
The Shimanami Kaido is about 60 km long expressway, which connects the Onomichi City in Hiroshima pref. and Imabari City in Ehime pref, passing over six islands in the Seto Inland Sea and allows passage by bicycle. There are cycle rental shops, so enjoy cycling and beautiful scenery!!! Have you been there before? If so, let us share your experience!! 
Imabari Area: https://www.jnto.go.jp/eng/location/regional/ehime/imabari_ozu.html
Shimanami-Kaido: http://www.jnto.go.jp/eng/location/spot/natuscen/shimanamikaido.html
comments:
Japan is the best country to go cycling in.  The road and trail conditions couldn't be better.

One tip: if you're coming from a country where you drive on the right side of the road, switch your brake cables around from left to right.  The two biggest reasons for doing this are: 1) If you brake while you hand signal you wont be squeezing the front brake, which can cause you to flip over head first, and 2) you can use your right hand to drink from your water bottle--as well as a lot of other things--safely.$$Did 17km with 2 local guides, cycling is a great way to explore. http://www.hiroshimatours.info/?page_id=1041$$I'll keep that in mind when I visit.  I love cycling!$$There's even a bicycle-related shrine nearby, with special rituals and amulets for cyclists. It's called the Bicycle shrine - Ëá™Ëª¢Ëªä„ÅÆÁ•ûÁ§æ.$$I been there last year! I love Onomichi and the Shinami Kaido! I rode the whole road in a day with a rental bicycle, coming  back to Onomichi with a bus. Wonderful experience!!$$When will we visit this place???
#stillkeepourdream
cc: Nurjihad Sokku AH Shiddiq$$I've done that before, great memory:)
If you're gonna rent a bike in Onomichi should be an early bird.
We couldn't get them and moved to the next island by ferry, where we managed to rent bikes.$$Yes!!!  Been there, done that...  It was wonderful!!!$$Getting a bike from Imabari City would be easier.$$Japan is a beatiful cpuntry and I would like visit this city and has a friends of this wonderful  city.$$I have been... I love Japan$$I never been there in my life

message+desc: Off the eastern coast of Sumatra, flanked by the Gaspar and Karimata Straits, lies an enchanting island with beautiful beaches and fascinating scenery called:  Belitung Island. Its unique landscape, decorated with pearly white sand beaches, crystal clear water, and magnificent granite stone formations on its shallow shores, are some of the best features of the island. http://goo.gl/F8SFQY #WonderfulIndonesiaBelitung Island has unique landscape, decorated with pearly white sand beaches, crystal clear water, and magnificent granite stone formations on its shallow shores, are some of the best features of the island.

message+desc:
[$250 SUSHI GIVEAWAY!] What Ordering Food In Singapore May Look Like In 2030

It's hard to imagine using the internet on your phone was impossible 10 years ago. Over the next decade, things are going to get even more crazy.

To printing your own food and chicken rice being served to your HDB 12 stories in the air, this may be the future in 2030.

Prove that you're an InDIYpendent Singaporean and win 5 x $50 Genki Sushi vouchers! All you'll have to do is:

1. Like and share THIS post
2. Comment here on how technology has made life more flexible.

Contest ends 15 July 2016. The most creative entries will win. Good luck!

http://thesmartlocal.com/read/ordering-food-futureFrom drone deliveries to 3D food printing, find out how else our eating habits will change by the time year 2030 rolls around!

Congratulations Cecilia Chng, Muhammad Arif, Sharon Yokaco, Tan Bee Chin Joyce, Wei KC!  You've all been picked as winners for this giveaway. Please PM us with your Full Name (as in NRIC), last 4 characters of NRIC (Sxxxx123A), and we'll get back to you shortly!$$Gone are the days of writting long letters. Today, technology has made it possible to send message across literally with just a finger touch. The most important documents and communications are digitally sent across the world and are delivered within seconds. Facebook is one of them, it helps to make the world more open and connected. Technology is the force behind it. Now this is what you call making life easier and flexible.$$Due to the amazing advances in technology over the last 10 years, a lot of us now have access to variety in almost every aspect of our lives. If we need a ride, there is no need to stand by a roadside waiting for a cab or to call a cab. Now we whip out our phones and within a few presses a cab comes to us, through apps like Grab, Uber, and even Ryde. We dont have to go to travel agencies and ask which hotel is the best. We just go on Expedia or AirBnB to find accomodation that suits us best. All these examples really reflect how flexible our lives have become because of technology.$$Internet banking has made my life easier by being able to pay my bills before the clock strikes 12mn, so that I won't be liable for late fees! we need technology to enhance efficiency !

Annie Tan-Yeo$$#WeAreInDIYpendent #FastEasyFlexible DIY machine are great, they have helped us to reduce waiting/queuing time. When ATM machine and AXS first came out it was a great help in reducing waiting time and make life easier and more efficient and as times goes by, technology improve and we now have mobile AXS apps on our phone. This is DIY 2.0, it is an evolution from the standalone DIY machine and has make life even easier for us as we can use it anytime, anywhere.
I am waiting for the day my mobile banking apps can let me withdraw and deposit cash, i believe that day will come$$As an 18 year old man / boy / guy / student, technology has vastly improved my life. 
First of all, lets talk food. Applications like foodpanda, deliveroo, mcdelivery , ect has made ordering of food through calls a thing from the past . We can order food so easily now,  by just tapping, swiping, ordering and paying . " Hardworking" and "busy" students like me don't have to waste time , going to a hawker centre or fastfood restaurants to queue and wait for food now . There are even apps like Honestbee and RedMart  , that delivers groceries to our homes. 
Secondly , we have applications like zalora , cotton on , sephora , that allows us to order fashion items back to our homes without travelling. We can even buy gifts for our friends through apps like these . Its fast , easy and definitely it has made our lives more flexible . 
There are so many things i can say about technology , though it has it's downs , the ups greatly overthrows them . It's 1:36 am and I have school tomorrow , so imma go now . HAHA i hope i can win those vouchers , cuz i really wanna eat sushi :< And i would love to intern at THESMARTLOCAL.COM ( Sings the theme song ) But i would save that talking for another day :)$$Technology has made life much more flexible in so many different aspects; messaging applications have bridged the gaps between us and have allowed us to connect to one another and share more of our personal lives with each other on the go, real time, even when we're physically apart. Mobile applications have also made it possible for us to pick up languages and other skills during those bus rides & MRT rides, turning self-improvement in our packed school/work lives from a fairy tale to reality. :) With all this advancement of technology, we are now more inspired to further technology, and imagine a better, more flexible future for ourselves. :)$$Liked and shared

I am a InDIYpendent Singaporean in overseas too. I remembered during my last customer visit in Shanghai. When I boarded the plane bound for Shanghai, I saw many business travellers boarding the planes with cakes and gifts for their clients or maybe their loved ones. As a InDIYpendent, I simply place my cake orders from a portal and they delivered to my hotel. So simple. No sweat.$$The advanced in technology has made travelling a less-hassle, enjoy our favourite food as and when we want and also time-saving when it comes to shopping and grocery buying. This was not even possible 5 years ago and we can see how fast technology has progress to enable us to lead a fuss-free life. What i envision in 2030 to be more convenient and faster than the current technology just like those in superheroes movie XD$$1. Like and share THIS post
2. Technology has made life more flexible. We can now order food online and have it delivered to our homes. Video Chat with family from oversea. It is like they are just next to us. And we no longer need to go to the library or book store to get the books we love. Just dowload the ebook for your reading pleasure anywhere and any time.$$The convenience technology has provided us can be felt not just by customers, but also by those working in the f&b line. Taking of orders used to be by paper and pen, which is not just troublesome and time consuming, and order papers could be easily lost or destroyed. But now with technology, we can easily key in the orders into the cashier and immediately both service and kitchen would have machines churning out the orders without mistake through wireless internet. And now customers can get their food and be happy B| 
(liked and shared~)$$technology has made life more flexible in three ways. 
one, when i am stuck in a deserted toilet with no toilet paper i no longer have to use my socks or wait 300 years for someone to come, i can just call someone with my handphone to come down with supplies.
two, when i am the loner at the party i no longer have to stare around awkwardly, i can whip out my phone and pretend i have a life and so many people are messaging me oh gosh.
three, when i see all the cool new phones and lappies i gotta catch em all so technology has given me new and innovative ways to become a poor and bankrupt student.$$Long long time ago when I was in my late teens and early twenties, I have many friends who broke up because one partner is going overseas to study. A few more years down the road came msn then Skype and now FaceTime. If they are born in this era, they wouldn't need to break up la. They have the flexibility to video call on PC/ Laptop or FaceTime/message/call using various phone apps. Technology have saved many ‚ù§Ô∏èrelationships‚ù§Ô∏è.$$Liked & shared! Technology make my life wonderful and handphone is the best invention. Handphone is a great companion, a BFF. Whenever I feel bored, I can play games with it, watch movies with it and listen music with it. My life becomes colourful and all my troubles are waived off.$$Liked & shared! Technology make my life more flexible and convenient when I am hungry and need for food I can simply call for delivery without even stepping out of my house! I can contact my friends with Watapp on mobile phone and stay in touch with friends through Facebook and messenger! No more letter writing which take time to reach my friends save on paper and effortlessly to stay in touch! Tagging Jennifer Ong Boon Chye$$I love how technology allows and helps me in communicating with people on the other side of the world. I would look forward to every night as i would be able to video call my mom as she moved to Thailand. We would talk about everything and anything HAHAHA it almost felt like we were side by side and things were the same like when i was a little kid. I am kind of an awkward potato andddddd im an introvert. I used to bury my head in books and not socialize with people of my age but playing online games has helped me out tremendously as it made me feel comfortable talking to strangers and connect with people from other parts of the world. From chatting behind a computer screen and slowly to video chatting with my best friend from maplestory. She has helped me to become a more social person and made me feel comfortable in my skin because I was made fun of alot in school and was an outcast. But, she was there for me and I would always look forward to going home and pouring my emotions out to her. She was a good listener. She taught me to create a blog and let me share about my life experiences. I'm so glad technology was invented and really glad that i have met my first true friend :)$$Technology has made life so much more flexible in so many ways. Communication is one of the aspects that have become much more convenient. Previously, once the date and time have been fixed, it is hard to change it at the very last minute. With smartphones, we can now create group chats and update everyone on the date and time to meet with a simple message. Also, it has allowed many cross-border exchanges, be it travelling or business deals, and strangers, friends and even families are able to connect despite being in different countries.

Liked and shared the post! :)$$I remember when we used to enter contests by tearing out pages from magazines/newspapers and mailing them by postage to the company's office, and we receive our prize through mailing too! Now with technology, we just need to "like and share" and most of the prizes are e-vouchers which is convenient! :)$$Press a button, money transfer over. Press another button food flies over. So shiok! We are very fortunate to be living in this era, everything got shortcuts now. Heng ah! I'm sure in the years ahead, we will see revolutionary changes in the way we lead our lives. Look forward to more exciting developments in the next generation of technological advancements. Hope I can still keep up with it in my 60s, 70s... :) Our lives will be more intertwined with technology!$$Technology has made my life easier and more convenient. From online banking to online shopping to ordering your taxi from your smart device. All it takes is a push of a button and sometimes you may not even have to own a credit card to enjoy having everything sent to your doorstep. Yes, some shops accepts COD! :-) But what I love most about these modern conveniences is that I get to spend more time with my kids and husband. The time supposed to be spent in walking to Sheng Siong and hauling 30 kilos of grocery with 2 howling kids in tow is now better spent playing catch in the park or watching movies at home with my feet propped up. Other than that, I am on extended maternity leave because I can work from home and submit my reports online. How cool is that? Perhaps I will order that chicken rice from that flying boat after all. Kristina OngDee Kaytee Polyndevilla Vic Peng$$Technology has definitely made life more flexible by allowing me to order fast food like MacDonald's, Pizza Hut, KFC etc with the click of my hand. It totally helps when I stranded at home with 2 little ones. 

Liked n shared!$$As Singaporeans, we love our food as much as we love our choices. With the advancements in technology, not only has our food become more delicious, dining has become more fun as well.

For instance, many would agree that having sushi off the conveyor belt not only allows us to dine at our own pace, the myriad of choices is also part of the fun. 

Having Korean BBQ wouldn't be as fun if the meat came to your table properly grilled as opposed to cooking it to your desired doneness, thanks to technology that makes it possible for diners to grill the meat and eat it right after.

And what about designing your own fluffy pancakes from bottles of pre-coloured pancake batter? 

All these dining experiences would not have been possible if technology did not exist - no longer do we need to prepare food beforehand before sitting down to a meal with friends or family - with technology, even the cooking can be an activity that bonds people.

We cannot deny that the future of food is closely linked with the advancement in technology. After all, one day we may be able to have our meals in a self-driving vehicle while taking in the beautiful scenery - life does not get more flexible than that. ;)$$Technology made our lives easier by allowing us to read almost everything and anywhere via our smartphones, so now I can just read stories and articles (esp thesmartlocal articlea :P) on the go!

message+desc: The majestic Borobudur Temple in Central Java is the largest Buddhist monument in the world.Recognized as a UNESCO World Cultural Heritage monument, the 9th century Borobudur Temple is truly a site that will boggle the mind. The perfect time to travel to the Borobudur Temple this year would be on May 11th 2017 because this is when Buddhists from Indonesia and other countries congregate at the temple to celebrate the holy Vesak Day. #WonderfulIndonesiaBe awed by the wondrous beauty of the world's biggest Buddhist monument on the island of Java. Explore Borobudur temple in indonesia.travel!
comments: Indeed the Borobudur temple is an amazing building but sorry to correct you this great temple is not listed in any current 7 wonders of the world compilation! It is for sure included in the UNESCO's World Cultural Heritage list, but it is not a part of the 7 world wonders....you can find information easily in Wikipedia and other sources....this is just not true.....cc$$I been there, amazing...$$Looking foward to visit Borobudur at sunrise this coming February! So excited!$$We have climbed Borobudur 3 times ....its certainly worth the effort.....very magical at the top.

message+desc: A dreamy vision of colors at Samgwangsa Temple in Busan. See more amazing photos like this >>>  http://bit.ly/UO24Fb
comments: Where is this temple located in busan? how many minutes or hours would i take if the route starts at the airport?$$It really takes time to make this spectacular view$$so beautiful and colorfull :)$$The character in the centre resembles eerily of a swastika to warrant my liking.$$Will I see this if I come by this weekend?$$.-. Sorry, but  isnt that nazi's symbol? omg. really sorry ._.$$In eastern teachings swastika means eternity or higher being while during WW II Hitler's Arian movement meant what it the world has become to known it as much twisted & malevolent value to such a peaceful symbol!$$The swastika was the symbol of good fortune, prosperity, and longevity in many Far Eastern countries. The word swastika comes from the Sanskrit svasti, which means good fortune, luck, and well-being. In Buddhism, the swastika represents the turning of the ‚ÄúDharma wheel‚Äù, and thereby promotes goodwill, compassion, and generosity to all sentient beings. Regrettably, Adolf Hitler and the National Socialist German Workers Party borrowed the swastika in the early 1900s, reversed it, and used it as their party emblem during World War II. Not only do the Nazi swastika and the ancient swastika used in Buddhism and Eastern cultures differ in meaning, the Nazi swastika is also slanted, resting on a point, and has right angles bent in a clockwise direction. The traditional swastika lays flat and is counterclockwise.$$The "swastika" symbol is seen all over the Buddhist temples!  It is actually a VERY ancient symbol with that has been used by Hinddis (? Sp) & Buddhists.  It has a more complex meaning than what I wrote.$$thanks for the info. Julius Reed  ^^$$wow what a magical colors in south korea the kingdom of the light and the beauty i really like the castle and the colors

message+desc:
Where would you like to visit while you‚Äôre sightseeing in Kyoto? If you use the Keihan Railway, with easy access to many famous sightseeing spots, like Fushimi-Inari Taisha Shrine, Gion district, Kiyomizu-dera Temple, Sanjusangen-do Temple, and Byodoin Temple, all of these locations will be within close walking distance of the stations on the Keihan Line. 
Let's ride the rails with this discounted, unlimited-use, sightseeing pass, which is only available to foreign travelers discovering Japan!

Learn more: http://japan-magazine.jnto.go.jp/en/special_keihan.html

message+desc:
Jammu - City of Temples
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Appropriately called the City of Temples because of the profusion of shrines dotting the landscape, Jammu is a travel destination on its own right. Studded with an incredibly beautiful landscape, this southernmost unit of the state of Jammu & Kashmir nestles in the foothills of the Himalayas. 

Once seat of power of the Dogra Rajas, this winter capital of the state is the leaping off point for the magnificent religious and natural attractions that lure the tourists and devotees to the other parts of the region. In Jammu you can visit beautiful temples, palaces and relics of the past and enjoy the city‚Äôs peaceful atmosphere with delightfully stunning tourist sights. 

- See more at: http://incredibleindia.org/index.php/travel/destination/jammu

message+desc:
The Aceh Tsunami Museum located in Banda Aceh, Indonesia. It is designed by Indonesian architect Ridwan Kamil as a symbolic reminder of the 2004 Indian Ocean Earthquake and Tsunami disaster as well as an educational center and an emergency disaster shelter, in case there‚Äôs another tsunami in the future. The museum is a 2.500 m2 four-storey and it acknowledges both the victims, whose names are to be inscribed on the wall of one of the museum‚Äôs internal chamber and the surviving members of the local community. http://ow.ly/RGIrv

#WonderfulIndonesia #PesonaIndonesia

message+desc:
The Guardian Takes STB Money, Then Writes A Super Biased Article Slamming Singapore.

When The Guardian is not taking Singapore's advertising money, they write shockingly inaccurate articles like this. I guess it's getting trendy in the UK to bash Singapore.

http://mustsharenews.com/guardian-denounces-singapore/When The Guardian is not taking Singapore's advertising money, they write articles like this. I guess it's getting trendy in UK to bash Singapore.
comments: Ubiquitous hectoring signage is a better album name than songs for fallen stars? Reminds me of when I tried to persuade my first band to call ourselves tubular scaffolding. It was 1975 right enough. I'll get me co-at.$$It's not the fact of having laws and rules that's the problem it's the ubiquitous hectoring signage that gets up my nose. Last week I counted 11 signs on the no. 7 bus alone telling me do do or not do various things.  Why do the public authorities seem to think people need to be constantly treated like naughty children?

message+desc:
Laro tayo! Patintero is a famous Filipino children's game, usually played outdoors on streets, school yards or beaches. It is played by 2 teams on a grid, where one team tries to pass through while the opposing team tries to catch them without stepping off the lines. Be a More Fun Advocate and share or teach this to your friends! 

Photo taken from certifiedgeek07.wordpress.com
comments: we stilll play patintero in our school...... love it.

message+desc:
Kyoto is a wonderful city for not only visiting traditional places but also going shopping. There is a shopping street, called "Shin-kyogogu" located in Shijo Kawaramachi. You can enjoy shopping souvenirs as well as various modern clothes and stuff with reasonable prices! It's fun to walk through the shopping arcade in the picture! If you love shopping, you can't miss this spot! 

Shopping in Kyoto: http://www.jnto.go.jp/eng/attractions/shopping/shopguide/kyoto.html

Shinkyogoku-dori Street: http://www.pref.kyoto.jp/visitkyoto/en/theme/amusement/downtown/st_shinkyogoku/
comments: Kyoto is the best! Rules!$$I LOVE THIS STREET. I'm in Kyoto right now and I just got back from shopping there! haha$$Really nice area for shopping and tasty restaurants$$I've been there! Lovely place!$$My friend and I are going to Japan this summer! Our current plan is to stay for 11 nights in Tokyo (with multiple day trips outside of Tokyo) and 3 nights in Kyoto (with a day trip to Nara). Here's my Japan Bucket List: http://www.mydreamcametrue.com/japan I'd love to hear about your favorite experiences and places to eat (especially inexpensive restaurants popular with the locals and restaurants with great vegetarian options) in Tokyo Disneyland, Tokyo DisneySea, Tokyo, Kyoto, Hakone, Kamakura, Yokohoma, Nikko, Kyoto, and Nara. After I return, I'll be writing reviews of my adventure. An index of my Japan reviews will be posted here: http://www.mydreamcametrue.com/japan$$Bought a lot of Japanese spices and souvenirs there. Will go there again next year. Backpacking in Japan is Simply Beautiful.
